unnormalised: Someone asked me, "How much should I donate to charity?" Well, it's a really personal question, isn't it? I remember when I first started earning, fresh out of college. My salary was just Rs. 25,000 per month, and living in Mumbai felt so expensive! But I still wanted to give back.
normalised: Someone asked me, "How much should I donate to charity?" Well, it's a really personal question, isn't it? I remember when I first started earning, fresh out of college. My salary was just rupees twenty five thousand per month, and living in Mumbai felt so expensive! But I still wanted to give back.

unnormalised: I started small, donating Rs. 500 to a local NGO working with underprivileged kids. It didn’t seem like much, but the smiles on their faces were priceless. Then, during the Kerala floods a few years ago, I donated Rs. 2000 to the CM's relief fund. Seeing the devastation on TV, I felt compelled to do more. My friend, Aisha, she actually donated 10% of her salary every month, which I always admired.
normalised: I started small, donating rupees five hundred to a local N-G-O working with underprivileged kids. It didn’t seem like much, but the smiles on their faces were priceless. Then, during the Kerala floods a few years ago, I donated rupees two thousand to the C-M's relief fund. Seeing the devastation on T-V, I felt compelled to do more. My friend, Aisha, she actually donated ten percent of her salary every month, which I always admired.

unnormalised: Later, as my income increased, I began donating to different causes. I'd contribute ₹1000 to animal shelters, and then during festivals like Diwali, I would buy sweets worth approx. Rs 1500 for children in orphanages. I also once saw a fundraiser where they needed $5000 for a young girl's heart surgery. That one really got to me.
normalised: Later, as my income increased, I began donating to different causes. I'd contribute rupees one thousand to animal shelters, and then during festivals like Diwali, I would buy sweets worth approximately rupees one thousand five hundred for children in orphanages. I also once saw a fundraiser where they needed dollar five thousand for a young girl's heart surgery. That one really got to me.

unnormalised: Honestly, there's no magic number. Think about what you can comfortably afford without impacting your financial stability. Could you skip that Friday night movie and donate Rs. 300 instead? Could you forego one new outfit a month and donate Rs. 1000? Every little bit counts, truly.
normalised: Honestly, there's no magic number. Think about what you can comfortably afford without impacting your financial stability. Could you skip that Friday night movie and donate rupees three hundred instead? Could you forego one new outfit a month and donate rupees one thousand? Every little bit counts, truly.

unnormalised: So, the best answer I can give you is: Donate what feels right for you. Whether it's Rs. 100 or Rs. 10,000, the intention matters most. Plus, don't forget to claim the tax benefits under Section 80G!
normalised: So, the best answer I can give you is: Donate what feels right for you. Whether it's rupees one hundred or rupees ten thousand, the intention matters most. Plus, don't forget to claim the tax benefits under Section eighty G!
